title: Nationals responded to controversial Turner call by leaving no doubt in Game 6
text:
The Nationals’ response? It can’t be printed here. The result, though, can: They shrugged off what could have been a World Series-altering controversy and beat the Houston Astros, 7-2 . With steam coming out of their ears, they forced a Game 7. They took tumult and beat it back, with Stephen Strasburg’s latest defining October start and Anthony Rendon’s absolute rebuke — to the Astros, to the umps, to everyone outside that dugout — of a two-run homer.

Manager Dave Martinez was ejected? Juan Soto upstaged Astros braggart Alex Bregman with a titanic blast off Justin Verlander to take the lead? They seem like footnotes now. In a World Series that meandered through the first five games searching for a signature moment, Tuesday night provided a half dozen.

AD

AD

Oh, and it leads to this: Max Scherzer vs. Zack Greinke on Wednesday night for the championship.

Inhale. Exhale. Inhale. Exhale.

Okay, let’s review. It’s worth it. Believe me.

The most memorable play of a dizzying evening came in the seventh with the Nats up 3-2 with no outs and Gomes on first. Turner hit the ball in question, a spinner in front of the mound that Houston reliever Brad Peacock — long ago a Nats draft pick — picked up and gunned to first. The throw led Astros first baseman Yuli Gurriel to move his glove to his left, into Turner’s path.

As Turner ran past, Gurriel’s glove popped off. Peacock’s throw hit Turner in the back of the leg. The ball sprayed free. The result seemed obvious: Gomes to third, Turner to second.

AD

And then home plate umpire Sam Holbrook got involved. Holbrook ruled Turner had interfered with Gurriel by running on the inside of the baseline. Replays showed this was dubious. Had Peacock’s throw been to the inside of the bag, Gurriel and Turner wouldn’t have been near each other, and Turner probably would have beaten it.

AD

When Holbrook made his call and sent Gomes back to first, the Nats went ballistic — and then protested the game to Major League Baseball. Turner, whose heart rate rarely ticks up, was livid in the dugout. It took 4½ minutes for the umpires, communicating with MLB officials, to reaffirm that Turner was out and, apparently, acknowledge the Nats’ protest — though the protest was never announced.

What’s beautiful about this mess? Rendon and Strasburg made it not matter.

AD

With two outs and Gomes still on first, Rendon feasted on a cutter from Houston reliever Will Harris. His two-run shot landed in the Crawford Boxes in left. The 43,384 at Minute Maid Park who came to see their team crowned a champion fell silent. The Nats’ dugout went ballistic.

Inhale. Exhale. Do it again.

It would seem impossible for a team to rewrite its well-earned postseason persona in one month, but these Nationals have done that. The three games over the weekend at Nationals Park showed that. They were, from the home side, all duds. The crowds, all three nights, maintained hope. The people who filed in didn’t change their expectations. The Nationals, with their actions and antics, altered those outlooks for them.

AD

AD

It matters now — for what’s to come Wednesday night, not to mention 2020 and beyond — that there is evidence the Nationals will step into the spotlight and thrive rather than run into a closet to hide. Drew Storen vs. Pete Kozma, Clayton Kershaw vs. Daniel Murphy, Matt Wieters melting down — those defining moments are still part of Octobers past for Washington. They just have company.

In that sense, the fifth inning Tuesday night fits — because they entered with a deficit against Verlander and exited with a lead. This team can draw from the moments when it flipped things this fall — Soto’s eighth-inning, lead-changing hit against Milwaukee in the wild-card game, homers from Rendon and Soto off Kershaw to force extra innings in Game 5 of the division series in Los Angeles, Howie Kendrick’s grand slam to win that game, the absolute throttling of St. Louis in the championship series sweep.

Collectively, this one trip to the postseason has produced more moments you’re likely to watch on YouTube over and over than the four previous trips combined. Then there was Jayson Werth’s shot to win Game 4 against St. Louis in 2012 and Strasburg’s rise-from-the-dead 12-strikeout performance to stave off elimination in Chicago against the Cubs in 2017. Anything else is kind of a stretch.

AD

AD

So back to the fifth Tuesday night. Verlander had done well to strand five Nats over the first four innings, continuing a theme that developed over the weekend in the District. Although Verlander held the lead, the Nats had missed their share of pitches. A team slump seemed to have settled in. And then with one out, Eaton came up.

Eaton, curiously or stupidly, had bunted in the first. What would the bunter do with an 0-1 slider from Verlander? Deposit it in the right field seats to tie the score. Two batters later, here came Soto. Play this one on continuous loop, from the release of Verlander’s 96-mph gas on the inside part of the plate, to the swing that assaulted the baseball, to Soto’s reaction, holding the bat until he had nearly reached first base — a troll of Bregman, who had taunted the Nats with the same braggadocio after his homer off Strasburg in the first.

Oh, Strasburg. Right. Him.

AD

AD

He didn’t need another signature moment in October, but now he has one. No pitcher has ever finished a postseason with a 5-0 record. That’s what Strasburg has now. The struggles in the first inning — two runs, shaky command — gave way to the dominant pitcher he has become.

Strasburg is now in such control of himself, of his craft, that he can correct himself midstream. On Tuesday night, the correction looked like this: an efficient, 8⅓ -inning, 104-pitch masterpiece in which he gave up just three hits after the first, in which he beat back two base runners in both the fourth and the fifth, in which he willed his team into Game 7.

Game 7. Game 7. Scherzer vs. Greinke. Nationals vs. Astros. Relive Tuesday night in a hurry. Sort through all the heroics. Inhale. Exhale. Because here it comes.

description: A controversial interference call. Dominance from Stephen Strasburg. Booming home runs to turn it around. And now, one game to decide it all.
authors: Sports Columnist With Beat Writing Experience On Baseball
